titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Robert A. Kennard Papers LSC.2351
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Amy Zhou, Allison Yang, and Eric Olsen, 2019-2021.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2024 February 2.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-20 14:11:24 -0800.

physdesc.extent: (58 boxes, 1 half box, 5 shoeboxes, and 2 flat boxes)
(90 unprocessed rolls, 7 unprocessed oversize boxes, 2 unprocessed flat boxes, 1 unprocessed folder)

did.abstract: Robert A. Kennard (1920-1995) was an African American architect in Los Angeles. He designed over 40 residences and later focused on public works, including Carson City Hall and Community Center and the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) Headquarters. The collection contains administrative records about his firm, Kennard Design Group (KDG); site plans, planning reports, and studies; photographs, negatives, and slides of completed projects; and documentation about Kennard's work in the National Organization of Minority Architects (NOMA) and mentorship to architects of color.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with the exception of the Architectural Plans series. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIO MATERIALS: Audio materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Robert A. Kennard papers (Collection 2351). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Amy Zhou, Allison Yang, and Eric Olsen in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), under the supervision of Courtney Dean, 2019-2021.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Robert A. Kennard was born in Los Angeles, CA in 1920. He served as a lieutenant in the Army in World War II and the Korean War, attended Pasadena City College, and earned an architectural degree at USC. In 1957 he established his own firm, later known as Kennard Design Group, the oldest African American architecture firm in Los Angeles. The firm designed more than 700 projects in Southern California, beginning with over 40 residences completed through the early 1960s. One of his first homes, the Zeiger Residence in Laurel Canyon has been designated as a City of Los Angeles Cultural-Historic Monument. In the mid-1960s he shifted his practice to public work. Notable projects include the City of Carson City Hall and Community Center, designed with architects Robert Alexander and Frank Sata, Van Nuys State Office Building with architect Harold Williams, and Parking Structures 1, 3 and 4 at the Los Angeles International Airport. Two of his last projects completed in the mid-1990s were the City of Los Angeles 77th Street Police Headquarters in which the community room is named in his honor, and a new entrance to the Hollywood Bowl.

Kennard Design Group garnered awards from the American Institute of Architects (AIA) and California Preservation Foundation for its work as associate architect in the redesign and expansion of Los Angeles' Central Library. Kennard encouraged other minority and women architects to enter the profession, and he was active in the both the Los Angeles and California chapters of the American Institute of Architects (AIA) and in numerous community organizations including the Inner City Cultural Center where he served as president of the board with the late actor, Gregory Peck. He was recognized as a fellow of the AIA, a Distinguished Alumnus of the USC School of Architecture, and he received the Whitney M. Young Jr. Citation from the AIA in 1991 for his contributions to the profession. He died in Los Angeles, CA, in March 1995.
Source: Myrna Oliver, "R. A. Kennard; Prominent Black Architect," Los Angeles Times, March 29, 1995, http://articles.latimes.com/1995-03-29/news/mn-48295_1_los-angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains administrative records about Robert Kennard's architecture firm, Kennard Design Group (KDG); site plans, planning reports, and studies; and documentation about Kennard's work in the National Organization of Minority Architects (NOMA) and mentorship to architects of color. The bulk of the material consists of photographs and negatives of KDG architectural projects, in addition to color slides and microfilm of drawings. Also contained within the collection are 125 rolled architectural drawings for KDG projects and 7 boxes of plans for Kennard's personal residence. The collection also contains a student portfolio of Kennard's.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection has been arranged in the following series:
Series 1: Kennard Design Group administrative records, 1953-2000s
Subseries 1.1: General administrative records, 1953-2000s
Subseries 1.2: Awards, 1974-2000
Subseries 1.3: Press and marketing, 1980-1999
Subseries 1.4: Correspondence, 1954-1995
Series 2: Kennard Design Group projects, 1957-2015
Subseries 2.1: Los Angeles County, 1957-2003
Subseries 2.2: Non-Los Angeles County Southern California, 1970-1988
Subseries 2.3: Northern California, 1968-2015
Subseries 2.4: Other US locations, 1970s-1980s
Subseries 2.5: International, 1970s-1983
Subseries 2.6: Color slides, microfilm, and negatives, 1960s-1995
Series 3: Architectural plans and drawings, 1959-1995
Series 4: Increasing diversity in architecture, 1976-1994

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Interview of Robert Kennard [oral history transcript] / Wesley H. Henderson, interviewer. UCLA Library Special Collections, Center for Oral History Research interview, 1990-1991. Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company records (Collection 1434). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises administrative documents, awards, marketing documents, reports, legal and financial information, newspaper articles, and personal correspondence realted to the operations of KDG.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes such items as professional photographs, listings of Board members for organizations that Kennard was a part of, examples of brochures, but also more critical administrative documents that contribute to an understanding of how Kennard ran his business, including documents outlining the dissolution of an earlier iteration of the KDG company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains awards and award submissions to a variety of different architectural competitions, in addition to exhibits in international or national architectural exhibitions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists primarily of newspaper and magazine clippings covering the 40th anniversary of KDG, Robert Kennard's death, and press coverage of various projects. Also included are clippings pertaining to Zimbabwe in the early 1980s, likely collected in relation to the Zanu (PF) Headquarters proposed project, and a small amount of marketing materials.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence from both individuals and organizations from and to Robert Kennard. Included is correspondence about Robert Kennard's passing and a note from Mayor Tom Bradley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series makes up the bulk of the collection and includes project documentation for work that KDG has completed over the years. Subseries 2.6 includes the photoslides that KDG had created for their projects.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material has been arranged chronologically by project job. Projects are arranged into subseries geographically per the location of the project site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries collects all of the projects that KDG completed and proposed in Los Angeles County, and includes site plans, photographs, transparencies, and negatives. KDG constructed many Los Angeles sites including the Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) Headquarters, Carson City Hall and Community Center and many fire stations, churches, high schools, and university buildings across the county.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 64 contains 6 reels: Temple Emanuel; Emergency Operation Center (463); UCLA Memorial Activities Center (524); UCSD (462); Liberty Square Parking Garage (610); Poway (618).
Box 65 contains 5 reels: Hyde Park School (258); Dance remodeling; UCSD academic unit 1 (379); Veterans Administration 60 Bed Nursing Home (558) (2 reels).

Box 66 contains 17 reels: St. Mark's Lutheran Church (316); Hunter's Point Child Care Center Site I (304) (2 reels); Harbor Dental (333); Temple Beth David (306); Central City Community Mental Health Center (270); Carson City Hall North Wing (528); Northwest Recreation Center (405); Crenshaw Probation (338); San Fernando Valley Child Guidance Clinic (364); St. John's Lutheran Church (324); UCLA Kerckhoff Hall (476); ERC Building (503); Oak Center Towers (358); Placentia, Main Post Office (367); Golden State Mutual (406); UCLA Campus Storehouse (439).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains negatives of drawings attached to cards for the following projects:

Temple Akiba (188); Los Angeles High School (LAUSD) (362); Third College (379); Carson City Hall (384); Bank of America (454); UCSD Third College Phase 2 (462); Carson Computer Facility (463); Carson North Basement (471); ERC (503).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Unprocessed series. This material is unavailable for access. Please see LSC's Access to Unprocessed Collections Policy for more information about levels of discovery and access of special collections materials and registering interest in unprocessed collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains 125 sets of rolled architectural drawings for KDG projects, and 7 boxes of drawings for Kennard's personal residence.

otherfindaid.p: A digital copy of the architectural drawings inventory is available via this link: Link to Kennard architectural drawings inventory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series comprises documents that outline Robert Kennard's commitment to increasing diversity in the field of architecture. It includes membership lists to organizations like the NAACP and the National Organization of Minority Architects.
